items.title_orig: PIA suspends operations to Gulf countries following strikes on Iran by Israel, US
items.summary_orig: The Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) on Saturday suspended its flights to Gulf countries due to the â€œevolving situation in the Middle Eastâ€. According to a statement by the PIA spokesperson, flights have been suspended to the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Bahrain, Doha, and Kuwait. â€œThese flights will not operate until tomorrow evening or until the restoration of airspace, whichever comes later,â€ the spokesperson said. â€œPIA flights to Saudi Arabia will continue; however, their routes have been changed,â€ he added. â€œFlights have been shifted to Boeing 777 aircraft and will reach their destinations via longer routes,â€ the spokesperson added. The national carrier requested the travelers to contact the PIA call centre at 111-786-786 for  information related to their flights or changes in the booking of flights.

items.title_orig: â€˜Bombing a sovereign country is not preemptiveâ€™: Politicians, activists react as US and Israel strike Iran
items.summary_orig: The United States and Israel launched a wave of strikes against targets in Iran on Saturday, triggering explosions in the capital Tehran and an escalation across the region. â€œWe are going to destroy their missiles and raze their missile industry to the ground. It will be totally â€” again â€” obliterated. Weâ€™re going to annihilate their navy,â€ said US President Donald Trump in an address from his Florida home posted to his Truth Social platform. On the other hand, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the operation aimed to â€œremove the existential threat posed by the terrorist regime in Iranâ€, and urged Iranians to overthrow the Islamic Republicâ€™s clerical leadership. In response to the Israel-US aggression, the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps of Iran later in the day confirmed the launch of the â€œfirst waveâ€ of missile and drone attacks against Israel in response to the strikes on its territory. Political figures and analysts in Pakistan have condemned the recent developments, particularly criticising US President Donald Trump, and warned that the escalation could have grave consequences for the region. In a statement issued by the PPP Media Cell, former foreign minister Bilawal Bhutto-Zardari condemned the Israeli attack on Iran, calling it a â€œmatter of serious concernâ€ for peace in the region. He further stated that the â€œcowardly attackâ€ by Israel was an attempt to cover its atrocities in Gaza. The PPP chairman also called on the United Nations and the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation to take all possible measures to stop the Israeli aggression. The international community should take notice of Israelâ€™s open violation of Iranâ€™s sovereignty and territorial integrity, he added. Author and journalist Zahid Hussain noted in a post on social media platform X that â€œpredictably, the US and Israel have attacked Iranâ€. â€œThe so-called â€˜peace time presidentâ€™ has invaded two countries and attacked several others in the first year of his term,â€ he added, seemingly referring to Trump, who has repeatedly claimed that he has played a role in stopping multiple wars. Hussain also warned that the â€œlatest US aggression will have serious consequences for Pakistan and the entire regionâ€. Pakistanâ€™s former ambassador to the US, UK and United Nations Maleeha Lodhi called on Pakistan to condemn the US-Israeli aggression against Iran â€œwithout delayâ€. â€œThe people of Pakistan expect no less than to stand in solidarity with Iran,â€ she said in a post on X. Meanwhile, former senator Mushahid Hussain Sayed pointed out that the Israeli-American aggression against Iran has â€œgrave implicationsâ€ for the region and Pakistan. â€œIf God forbid, Iran loses, then Israelâ€™s de facto border will be at Taftan on the Pakistan border [â€¦] India-Israeli axis will tighten the squeeze on Pakistan, creating a nutcracker situation. â€œBalochistan and Pakistanâ€™s nuclear program could then also be targeted! Hence, urgent need for Pakistan to defuse tensions with Afghanistan as well as give a healing touch at home to defuse political polarisation,â€ he said. Lawyer and human rights professional Reema Omer noted that â€œpreventativeâ€ or â€œpreemptiveâ€ attacks had no basis in international law. â€œThey are mere euphemisms for the crime of aggression, i.e. the use of force against another state without legal justification,â€she wrote on X. â€œThe International Military Tribunal at Nuremberg described the crime of aggression as the â€˜supreme international crimeâ€™ as it â€˜contains within itself the accumulated evil of the wholeâ€™,â€ she added. Jamaat-i-Islami Pakistan former emir Sirajul Haq termed the attack on Iran â€œstate terrorismâ€ and urged Muslims to unite instead of â€œmerely condemning it and waiting for their turnâ€. â€œFollowing Israeli aggression, Muslim countries should announce their withdrawal from Trumpâ€™s so-called peace board,â€ he said. Former human rights minister Shireen Mazari said: â€œTerrorist Israel has launched multiple attacks against Iran just as Iran and the US were supposedly near an agreement. â€œGiven the lack of support within the US to attack Iran, Trump most likely sought an attack by Israel, knowing Iran would respond, which would allow the US to â€˜justifiablyâ€™ attack Iran.â€ Separately, journalist Iftikhar Firdous said that with Iran being attacked during an active conflict between Pakistan and Afghanistan, the entire Western border strip â€œis now under fireâ€. â€œThe dynamics that emerge out of this conflict will shape global and regional geopolitics for the decades to come,â€ he wrote in a post on X. Majlis Wahdat-i-Muslimeen (MWM) chief and Senate opposition leader Allama Raja Nasir Abbas condemned the â€œreckless and unlawful military attacks launchedâ€ against Iran. â€œThis timing makes it clear that the talks were used as cover for a pre-planned aggression. Diplomacy was sabotaged deliberately. Who can trust any negotiation process now when advances in talks lead straight to bombardment? The Israeli claim of a â€˜preemptiveâ€™ strike is absurd. There was no evidence Iran planned any attack on Israel,â€ he said. â€œSuch actions by the US under Trump and Israel under Netanyahu are a grave violation of international law, including the UN Charter. They risk turning the Persian Gulf and the wider Middle East into a catastrophe. The entire prospering region is now on fire because of this madness,â€ he said. He added that Iranâ€™s response was a â€œlegitimate act of self-defence under Article 51 of the UN Charterâ€. â€œI call on the government of Pakistan to categorically and unequivocally condemn this aggression against the Islamic Republic of Iran,â€ he said. Author and activist Fatima Bhutto said, â€œIf they succeed in Iran, Israel will turn to Pakistan next. They are the greatest threat to the world â€” a rogue terror state.â€ She further stated, â€œBombing a sovereign country is not preemptive. The only state that has a right to defend itself now is Iran. May they do it, they would acting on behalf of the world.â€ Former federal minister Khawaja Saad Rafique said that the Israeli attack on Iran with American backing was â€œstate terrorismâ€. â€œIt is the fundamental right of the Iranian people to determine Iranâ€™s national security priorities. The US and Israel cannot dictate this,â€ he said. â€œAttacks on Iran to prevent it from acquiring nuclear energy are nothing but global tyranny,â€ he said. Header imager: Smoke rises following an explosion, after Israel and the US launched strikes on Iran, in Tehran, Iran, February 28, 2026. â€” Reuters
items.title_en: â€˜Bombing a sovereign country is not preemptiveâ€™: Politicians, activists react as US and Israel strike Iran
items.summary_en: The United States and Israel launched a wave of strikes against targets in Iran on Saturday, triggering explosions in the capital Tehran and an escalation across the region. â€œWe are going to destroy their missiles and raze their missile industry to the ground. It will be totally â€” again â€” obliterated. Weâ€™re going to annihilate their navy,â€ said US President Donald Trump in an address from his Florida home posted to his Truth Social platform. On the other hand, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the operation aimed to â€œremove the existential threat posed by the terrorist regime in Iranâ€, and urged Iranians to overthrow the Islamic Republicâ€™s clerical leadership. In response to the Israel-US aggression, the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps of Iran later in the day confirmed the launch of the â€œfirst waveâ€ of missile and drone attacks against Israel in response to the strikes on its territory. Political figures and analysts in Pakistan have condemned the recent developments, particularly criticising US President Donald Trump, and warned that the escalation could have grave consequences for the region. In a statement issued by the PPP Media Cell, former foreign minister Bilawal Bhutto-Zardari condemned the Israeli attack on Iran, calling it a â€œmatter of serious concernâ€ for peace in the region. He further stated that the â€œcowardly attackâ€ by Israel was an attempt to cover its atrocities in Gaza. The PPP chairman also called on the United Nations and the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation to take all possible measures to stop the Israeli aggression. The international community should take notice of Israelâ€™s open violation of Iranâ€™s sovereignty and territorial integrity, he added. Author and journalist Zahid Hussain noted in a post on social media platform X that â€œpredictably, the US and Israel have attacked Iranâ€. â€œThe so-called â€˜peace time presidentâ€™ has invaded two countries and attacked several others in the first year of his term,â€ he added, seemingly referring to Trump, who has repeatedly claimed that he has played a role in stopping multiple wars. Hussain also warned that the â€œlatest US aggression will have serious consequences for Pakistan and the entire regionâ€. Pakistanâ€™s former ambassador to the US, UK and United Nations Maleeha Lodhi called on Pakistan to condemn the US-Israeli aggression against Iran â€œwithout delayâ€. â€œThe people of Pakistan expect no less than to stand in solidarity with Iran,â€ she said in a post on X. Meanwhile, former senator Mushahid Hussain Sayed pointed out that the Israeli-American aggression against Iran has â€œgrave implicationsâ€ for the region and Pakistan. â€œIf God forbid, Iran loses, then Israelâ€™s de facto border will be at Taftan on the Pakistan border [â€¦] India-Israeli axis will tighten the squeeze on Pakistan, creating a nutcracker situation. â€œBalochistan and Pakistanâ€™s nuclear program could then also be targeted! Hence, urgent need for Pakistan to defuse tensions with Afghanistan as well as give a healing touch at home to defuse political polarisation,â€ he said. Lawyer and human rights professional Reema Omer noted that â€œpreventativeâ€ or â€œpreemptiveâ€ attacks had no basis in international law. â€œThey are mere euphemisms for the crime of aggression, i.e. the use of force against another state without legal justification,â€she wrote on X. â€œThe International Military Tribunal at Nuremberg described the crime of aggression as the â€˜supreme international crimeâ€™ as it â€˜contains within itself the accumulated evil of the wholeâ€™,â€ she added. Jamaat-i-Islami Pakistan former emir Sirajul Haq termed the attack on Iran â€œstate terrorismâ€ and urged Muslims to unite instead of â€œmerely condemning it and waiting for their turnâ€. â€œFollowing Israeli aggression, Muslim countries should announce their withdrawal from Trumpâ€™s so-called peace board,â€ he said. Former human rights minister Shireen Mazari said: â€œTerrorist Israel has launched multiple attacks against Iran just as Iran and the US were supposedly near an agreement. â€œGiven the lack of support within the US to attack Iran, Trump most likely sought an attack by Israel, knowing Iran would respond, which would allow the US to â€˜justifiablyâ€™ attack Iran.â€ Separately, journalist Iftikhar Firdous said that with Iran being attacked during an active conflict between Pakistan and Afghanistan, the entire Western border strip â€œis now under fireâ€. â€œThe dynamics that emerge out of this conflict will shape global and regional geopolitics for the decades to come,â€ he wrote in a post on X. Majlis Wahdat-i-Muslimeen (MWM) chief and Senate opposition leader Allama Raja Nasir Abbas condemned the â€œreckless and unlawful military attacks launchedâ€ against Iran. â€œThis timing makes it clear that the talks were used as cover for a pre-planned aggression. Diplomacy was sabotaged deliberately. Who can trust any negotiation process now when advances in talks lead straight to bombardment? The Israeli claim of a â€˜preemptiveâ€™ strike is absurd. There was no evidence Iran planned any attack on Israel,â€ he said. â€œSuch actions by the US under Trump and Israel under Netanyahu are a grave violation of international law, including the UN Charter. They risk turning the Persian Gulf and the wider Middle East into a catastrophe. The entire prospering region is now on fire because of this madness,â€ he said. He added that Iranâ€™s response was a â€œlegitimate act of self-defence under Article 51 of the UN Charterâ€. â€œI call on the government of Pakistan to categorically and unequivocally condemn this aggression against the Islamic Republic of Iran,â€ he said. Author and activist Fatima Bhutto said, â€œIf they succeed in Iran, Israel will turn to Pakistan next. They are the greatest threat to the world â€” a rogue terror state.â€ She further stated, â€œBombing a sovereign country is not preemptive. The only state that has a right to defend itself now is Iran. May they do it, they would acting on behalf of the world.â€ Former federal minister Khawaja Saad Rafique said that the Israeli attack on Iran with American backing was â€œstate terrorismâ€. â€œIt is the fundamental right of the Iranian people to determine Iranâ€™s national security priorities. The US and Israel cannot dictate this,â€ he said. â€œAttacks on Iran to prevent it from acquiring nuclear energy are nothing but global tyranny,â€ he said. Header imager: Smoke rises following an explosion, after Israel and the US launched strikes on Iran, in Tehran, Iran, February 28, 2026. â€” Reuters

items.title_orig: US and Israel launch strikes on Iran: what we know so far
items.summary_orig: Explosions also reported in countries across the Middle East, with Trump calling the US operation â€˜massive and ongoingâ€™ Full report US-Israeli attack on Iran â€“ live updates On Saturday morning, the US and Israel launched a series of strikes on Iran. In response, Iranâ€™s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) said it had fired missiles against US military bases in the Gulf. Explosions were reported in Bahrain, Kuwait, the UAE and Qatar. One person was killed by shrapnel from an Iranian missile in the UAE, officials said. Explosions shook the Iranian capital Tehran, where people reported seeing smoke rising from the district that includes the presidential palace. Iran also launched waves of missiles at Israel, with blasts reported in the skies over Jerusalem. The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) said air defence systems were working to shoot down the â€œbarrage of missilesâ€ launched from Iran. Israeli officials told the media that top Iranian regime and military leaders, including Iranâ€™s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and president Masoud Pezeshkian, had been targeted in the attacks. It is believed that Khamenei is not in Tehran and has been taken to a secure location, while Iranian media is reporting that Pezeshkian is safe. The US president, Donald Trump, vowed that the â€œmassive and ongoingâ€ campaign against Iran would crush its military, eliminate its nuclear programme and bring about a change in government. â€œOur objective is to defend the American people by eliminating imminent threats from the Iranian regime, a vicious group of very hard, terrible people,â€ he said. The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said the operation was to remove an â€œexistential threatâ€. Talks between the US and Iran on Tehranâ€™s nuclear programme ended inconclusively on Friday, with a suggestion that further discussions would be held next week. Trump had said he was â€œnot happyâ€ with the progress of discussions . Continue reading...

items.title_orig: Greece advises Greek-flagged vessels to avoid some shipping routes after strikes on Iran
items.summary_orig: ATHENS, Feb 28 - Greece's shipping ministry advised Greek-flagged vessels on Saturday to exercise maximum vigilance and avoid the Persian Gulf, the Gulf of Oman and the Strait of Hormuz following strikes by the United States and Israel against Iran, according to an advisory seen by Reuters.

items.title_orig: UK says Iran must never be allowed to develop nuclear weapons
items.summary_orig: LONDON, Feb 28 - Britain said on Saturday that Iran must never be allowed to develop nuclear weapons and stood ready to defend its interests, following strikes by the United States and Israel against Iran.

items.title_orig: What we know about the joint US-Israeli air strikes on Iran
items.summary_orig: The US and Israel on Saturday launched a wave of air strikes against Iran, targeting what Israel said were dozens of military sites as well as the compound housing Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, whose whereabouts remain unknown. Here is what we know so far about the attack, which the Israeli military said has been months in the making.

items.title_orig: World holds breath as US, Israel strike Iran
items.summary_orig: Countries in the Middle East and around the world were watching with bated breath after the United States and Israel carried out long-feared strikes on Iran on Saturday. Trump: â€˜annihilateâ€™ US President Donald Trump vowed that the strikes would cripple Iranâ€™s military and urged Iranians to rise up against the Islamic republic. â€œWe are going to destroy their missiles and raze their missile industry to the ground. It will be totally â€” again â€” obliterated. Weâ€™re going to annihilate their navy,â€ Trump said in the address from his Florida home posted to his Truth Social platform. Calling on Iranians to stand up to their government, Trump added: â€œThe hour of your freedom is at hand.â€ But he also warned that â€œthe lives of courageous American heroes may be lost and we may have casualtiesâ€. Netanyahu â€˜cast off the yokeâ€™ Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the operation aimed to â€œremove the existential threat posed by the terrorist regime in Iranâ€, and urged Iranians to overthrow the Islamic republicâ€™s clerical leadership. â€œOur joint action will create the conditions for the brave Iranian people to take their destiny into their own hands,â€ Netanyahu added. â€œThe time has come for all the people of Iranâ€¦ to cast off the yoke of tyranny and bring about a free and peace-seeking Iran.â€ Russia: Talks a â€˜coverâ€™ Russia called on its citizens to leave Iran, with former president Dmitry Medvedev saying that talks with the United States had just been a â€œcoverâ€. â€œThe peacekeeper is at it again,â€ Medvedev, now the chair of Russiaâ€™s security council, said in a post on X. â€œThe talks with Iran were just a cover. Everyone knew that. So who has more patience to wait for the enemyâ€™s sorry end now?â€ he added. Qatar: â€˜secureâ€™ Qatar, which hosts a US military base, initially said it was secure after the US and Israeli attacks on neighbouring Iran but was monitoring developments closely. â€œThe situation inside the State of Qatar is stable and secure,â€ an interior ministry statement said. An official later told AFP that Qatari defence systems had intercepted an Iranian missile, and the defence ministry said it had repelled â€œa number of attacks.â€ Shahâ€™s son: â€˜final victoryâ€™ near - Reza Pahlavi, the son of Iranâ€™s last shah and a leading critic of Tehran, said that â€œwe are very close to final victoryâ€ following the strikes. â€œI want to be by your side as soon as possible so that together we can take back and rebuild Iran,â€ said Pahlavi, who lives in exile in the Washington area and had repeatedly urged Trump to intervene. Jordan: protect skies Jordanâ€™s military said its air force was at work on Saturday to protect the kingdom and its people while the strikes were ongoing. â€œThese sorties are part of aerial reconnaissance and inspection operations aimed at maintaining the safety of Jordanian airspace and ensuring that it is free from any attempts at infiltration or illegal activities,â€ a military source said, after sirens were reported in Amman. France: safety a priority France, which has several military bases in the Middle East, notably in Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Jordan, said that Parisâ€™s priority was the safety of its citizens. â€œObviously our priority in these sort of cases is the protection of our nationals, the protection of our forces in the region and the monitoring of the situation in real time, which we are doing,â€ Alice Rufo, minister-delegate to the Armed Forces and Veteransâ€™ Affairs ministry, told France 2 television. African Union: stability at risk The African Union called â€œfor restraint, urgent de-escalation and sustained dialogueâ€ after the strikes, warning that conflict could risk harming people on the continent. â€œFurther escalation risks worsening global instability, with serious implications for energy markets, food security, and economic resilience â€”  particularly in Africa, where conflict and economic pressures remain acute,â€ said the pan-African bodyâ€™s head, Mahamoud Ali Youssouf. Poland â€˜preparedâ€™ Polish staff at its embassy in Tehran were â€œsafeâ€ but the country is â€œprepared for various scenarios,â€ Prime Minister Donald Tusk wrote on X. Netherlands: â€˜restraintâ€™ In a post on X, Dutch Foreign Minister Tom Berendsen said: â€œThe Netherlands calls on all parties to exercise restraint and prevent further escalation. Stability in the region is essential.

items.title_orig: PTA urges citizens to avoid sharing â€˜unverified, inflammatoryâ€™ information amid heightened geopolitical tensions
items.summary_orig: The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) on Saturday issued an advisory cautioning citizens against sharing â€œunverified, inflammatory or misleading informationâ€ in light of the recent geopolitical situation. â€œIn view of the prevailing sensitive national situation, PTA urges all citizens to be responsible while using social media and digital platforms,â€ the body said, advising citizens not to â€œshare, disseminate, forward or upload information/content which is authentic and based upon official sources and to refrain from spreading rumours and fake newsâ€. PTA cautioned against sharing fake news or information â€œliable to legal action in accordance with applicable lawsâ€. â€œPTA calls upon all citizens to act with caution, maturity, and a strong sense of national responsibility to help, maintain stability and public confidence,â€ the statement added. The statement comes against the backdrop of escalating geopolitical tension in the Middle East, as Israel and the United States launched an attack on Iran on Saturday. Meanwhile, Pakistanâ€™s armed forces continue to counter the Afghan Taliban regimeâ€™s aggression on its western border as part of Operation Ghazab lil-Haq , which was launched against the Afghan Taliban after â€œunprovoked firingâ€ from across the border.

items.title_orig: 12-year-old Reseda girl dead after bully threw water bottle at her head, family says
items.summary_orig: A 12-year-old Reseda High School student is dead after a bully threw a metal water bottle at her head 10 days ago, according to the victimâ€™s family. The girlâ€™s mother, Elma Chuquipa, told KTLA that her daughter Khimberly was attacked by another 12-year-old girl who threw the water bottle at her in a school hallway.  [...]

items.title_orig: Pakistan faces monumental task against Sri Lanka in crucial Super Eight
items.summary_orig: Pakistan cricket remains in limbo as the Twenty20 showpiece cruises towards the summit after the Super Eights phase concludes this weekend. While the Group 1 match between toppers South Africa and Zimbabwe in Delhi will be inconsequential, Indiaâ€™s game against West Indies of the same group in Kolkata will be a virtual quarter-final. Prior to the Sunday double-header, calculators will be on the moment todayâ€™s last Group 2 contest between Pakistan and Sri Lanka explodes into action in Pallekele under lights. As usual, Pakistan cricket fans, including the disgruntled ones, remain in their typical fanciful mode â€” waiting for something extraordinary to happen in a global competition. The beleaguered Green-shirts under Salman Ali Agha face a monumental task: beating the Islanders in their backyard and winning it big, to qualify for the semi-finals. Having already exited the event, the co-hosts have nothing to lose, and so expect some instinctive fireworks from them. The real puzzle is faced by Pakistan, who â€” according to the stats â€” are required to win todayâ€™s game by 64 runs or achieve the winning target in 13.1 overs in order to improve their net run-rate to overtake New Zealandâ€™s overall scoring rate. Indeed, a mighty ask in the shortest slam-bang format. But itâ€™s not impossible, stats suggest. The highest T20 International score in Pallekele is 263-3, courtesy Glen Maxwellâ€™s thunderous 65-ball 145, posted by Australia some 10 years ago; Sri Lanka amassed 225-5 at the same venue against Oman in the ongoing event earlier this month; the co-hosts successfully chased down 182 in 18 overs at this venue against Australia earlier in this tournament, thanks to a 52-ball 100 by opener Pathum Nissanka. The same venue has produced low totals as well, including Sri Lankaâ€™s 95 that resulted in their 51-run loss to England in a Super Eights encounter less than a week ago as spinner Will Jacks (3-22) led the charge; and the hostsâ€™ 116 all out while chasing a modest 129 against the same country, as Jacob Bethell (4-11) and Jacks (3-14) stood out, just before the ongoing World Cup. Mammoth targets become achievable only if one scales their degree and requirements in time, and accordingly embraces the horses-for-courses stance. However, Pakistan cricket works differently and has remained wobbly in cut-throat International Cricket Council (ICC) events for years owing to a myriad of erroneous decisions in team selection. But wait here. This is not merely a problem of poor selection in Pakistan cricket. It runs deep. Inappropriate selection is just a prominent symptom. Though there are numerous complex causes for the alarming decline of Pakistan cricket that are difficult to address, one strongly feels stardom â€” and that too imagined, not proven fully â€” is one of the prime factors that has badly damaged the countryâ€™s cricket in recent years. Professional players around the world gradually make themselves stars through rigorous training, development and consistent performance in top-notch contests, of course with a proper system in place. Whereas in Pakistan the topsy-turvy system pushes a player to stardom. When individuals are preferred over prime collective goals for reasons best known to the decision-makers, the system starts to erode. Besides rusting the system, this decline quietly damages the individuals too. For this reason, comparing Babar, who has now spent over a decade in international cricket, to the great Virat Kohli now sounds humorous. Some may still disagree. Maxwell, Nissanka, Bethell and Jacks, or for that matter any other cricketer, are judged purely on the basis of their timely contributions in key contests â€”not due to their individual records that do not furnish victories for the team. Stats do not lie, particularly in T20 cricket in the contemporary era dominated by technology-based analysis. Sometimes they may be wrongly perceived and analysed due to various reasons, but figures do show a playerâ€™s overall utility for the team. Babar, who otherwise boasts a pretty decent T20 International batting stats, has not been able to justify his selection in the national team for World Cups â€” since he started representing Pakistan in the shortest format in 2021 â€” where he has managed just 640 runs so far in 21 innings at an average of 33.68 with a strike-rate of 111 which is regarded as below ordinary in modern-day T20 clashes. His 145-match T20 International career strike-rate is 128 which goes on to show that the batter has failed to meet the challenge specifically in high-pressure World Cup games. In the ongoing World Cup, the 31-year-oldâ€™s show with the bat, simple figures signify, has been way too ordinary. Scores of 15, 46 (against the USA), 5 and 25 plainly do not portray anything exceptional. In the Super Eights match against England, the batter consumed 24 balls for his 25, which slowed Pakistan down in the crucial middle overs. And it is not just stats that raise questions over Babarâ€™s visibly sluggish willow work in top-level T20 World Cup clashes. Does he have anything special in his stroke-making, any unorthodox-cum-beneficial batting style that can catch the opposition off guard? And how in this world can one deny his frailties against good-quality spinners? On what grounds can he be included in the playing XI for todayâ€™s outing that in all probability will demand brisk scoring? Can the profile of a player is bigger than the teamâ€™s fundamental needs on a given day? Due to Babarâ€™s inclusion in the playing XI of a T20 match, aggressive top-order stroke-player Fakhar Zaman has to be dropped down the order which at times simply kills the left-handerâ€™s game and eventually dents Pakistan in high-quality games of narrow margins. While considering the entire scenario, one strongly feels it will be a wise move by the team management if Babar is axed for todayâ€™s match. The way he was cleaned up in the present World Cup, both against India and England, very much shows frustration and lack of concentration and application in a player who otherwise is a classy shot-maker. In this situation, dropping him for todayâ€™s game will benefit Babar too who definitely needs a break â€” to recuperate and analyse himself. In this way, on one hand, the team management can give a chance to belligerent wicket-keeper/batter Khawaja Nafay or all-rounder Faheem Ashraf in the playing XI. Being pragmatic, the target for Pakistan today looks massive, and may well not be achieved even with Babar in the XI. Conversely, if a Babar-less Pakistan side manage to win todayâ€™s match against Sri Lanka and make the semi-finals, it will be considered a courageous move by the team management to earn the desired collective result. Subsequently, this will also create a significantly positive impact on the youngsters in the Green-shirtsâ€™ camp, and reduce pressure on Babar as well. The focus of the entire exercise in Pallekele today must be Pakistan cricket teamâ€™s progress and advancement, not that of any individual, let alone Babar. After all, this is a team sport, and currently the only one from which the nation has some hopes, though slim.

items.title_orig: Trump directs US agencies to toss Anthropicâ€™s AI as Pentagon calls startup a supply risk
items.summary_orig: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he is directing the government to stop work with Anthropic, and the Pentagon said it would declare the start-up a supply-chain risk, dealing a major blow to the artificial intelligence lab after a showdown about technology guardrails. Trump added there would be a six-month phase-out for the Defence Department and other agencies that use the companyâ€™s products. If Anthropic does not help with the transition, Trump said, he would use â€œthe Full Power of the Presidency to make them comply, with major civil and criminal consequences to followâ€. The actions mark an extraordinary rebuke by the United States against one of the premier companies that has kept it in the lead on national security-critical AI, threatening to give Anthropic a pariah status that Washington until now had reserved for enemy suppliers. Google and Amazon are among Anthropicâ€™s financial backers. The moves further set a precedent that US law alone would constrain how AI is deployed on the battlefield, with the Pentagon seeking to preserve all flexibility in defence and not be limited by warnings from the technologyâ€™s creators against powering weapons with unreliable AI. In a statement, Anthropic said it would challenge any risk designation in court by the Department of Defence, which the Trump administration has renamed the Department of War. â€œWe believe this designation would both be legally unsound and set a dangerous precedent for any American company that negotiates with the government,â€ the company said. â€œNo amount of intimidation or punishment from the Department of War will change our position on mass domestic surveillance or fully autonomous weapons.â€ Late on Friday, rival OpenAI, which is backed by Microsoft, Amazon and others, announced its own deal to deploy technology in the Defence Departmentâ€™s classified network. CEO Sam Altman on X said the Pentagon shared its principles for human responsibility over weapon systems and for having no mass US surveillance. â€œWe put them into our agreement,â€ Altman said of the points. â€œWe also will build technical safeguards to ensure our models behave as they should, which the DoW also wanted.â€ It was not immediately clear whether these contractual details differed from the red lines proposed by Anthropic. The Pentagon and OpenAI did not immediately respond to a request for comment. â€˜Nuclear Warâ€™ Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth said Anthropic would be designated a supply-chain risk, following an impasse in months of talks on whether the companyâ€™s policies could constrain military action. Meeting with Hegseth this week, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei argued for weapons and surveillance limits and irked Pentagon officials. The Pentagon said US law, not a private company, would determine how to defend the country. The designation could bar tens of thousands of contractors from using Anthropicâ€™s AI when working for the Pentagon. That represents an existential threat to its business with the government and could harm its private-sector relationships, said Franklin Turner, an attorney who specialises in government contracts. â€œBlacklisting Anthropic is the contractual equivalent of nuclear war,â€ he said. Similar US action was taken to remove Chinese tech giant Huawei from the Pentagonâ€™s supply chains. Starting in 2017, the US restricted Defence Department use of Huawei equipment, prohibited federal agencies from purchasing its technology, and halted federal grant and loan funds for Huawei equipment. Anthropic has raced to win fierce competition to sell novel technology to businesses and government, particularly for national security, ahead of a widely expected initial public offering. The company has said it has not finalised an IPO decision. Saif Khan, who served in the National Security Council in former President Joe Bidenâ€™s White House, said the Defence Departmentâ€™s action â€œmay be the most draconian domestic AI regulation any government has ever issued.â€ â€œThe Department is arguably treating Anthropic as a greater national security threat than any Chinese AI companies, none of whom theyâ€™ve designated supply-chain risks,â€ Khan said. â€˜Killer Robotsâ€™ Tech companies and the Pentagon have repeatedly locked horns since at least 2018, when employees at Google protested against the Pentagonâ€™s use of its AI to analyse drone footage. A rapprochement ensued with companies including Amazon and Microsoft jousting for defence business, while several big-tech CEOs pledged co-operation last year with the Trump administration. But theoretical â€œkiller robotsâ€ have worried human-rights and technology activists as wars in Ukraine and Gaza showcased increasingly automated systems. Bolder US military action in the past year has added to these concerns, said Jack Shanahan, who had directed the Pentagonâ€™s algorithmic warfare effort Project Maven. â€œPeople might be a little bit more nervous about no restrictions,â€ Shanahan said. The White Houseâ€™s legal sign-off could be â€œtop cover for anybody that does anything that would potentially result in lack of due process, civilian casualties, collateral damage.â€ The Pentagon signed agreements worth up to $200 million each with major AI labs in the past year, including Anthropic, OpenAI and Google. Anthropic, negotiating for awards under that ceiling, had flagged concerns about the legal systemâ€™s ability to keep up with AI progress. At present, for instance, US laws do not prevent the use of technology to compile seemingly innocuous data to reveal information about peopleâ€™s private lives, its CEO Amodei has said. Anthropicâ€™s AI has been in use across the intelligence community and armed services, and it was first among peer AI companies to work with classified information, through a supply deal via cloud provider Amazon.
items.title_en: Trump directs US agencies to toss Anthropicâ€™s AI as Pentagon calls startup a supply risk
items.summary_en: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he is directing the government to stop work with Anthropic, and the Pentagon said it would declare the start-up a supply-chain risk, dealing a major blow to the artificial intelligence lab after a showdown about technology guardrails. Trump added there would be a six-month phase-out for the Defence Department and other agencies that use the companyâ€™s products. If Anthropic does not help with the transition, Trump said, he would use â€œthe Full Power of the Presidency to make them comply, with major civil and criminal consequences to followâ€. The actions mark an extraordinary rebuke by the United States against one of the premier companies that has kept it in the lead on national security-critical AI, threatening to give Anthropic a pariah status that Washington until now had reserved for enemy suppliers. Google and Amazon are among Anthropicâ€™s financial backers. The moves further set a precedent that US law alone would constrain how AI is deployed on the battlefield, with the Pentagon seeking to preserve all flexibility in defence and not be limited by warnings from the technologyâ€™s creators against powering weapons with unreliable AI. In a statement, Anthropic said it would challenge any risk designation in court by the Department of Defence, which the Trump administration has renamed the Department of War. â€œWe believe this designation would both be legally unsound and set a dangerous precedent for any American company that negotiates with the government,â€ the company said. â€œNo amount of intimidation or punishment from the Department of War will change our position on mass domestic surveillance or fully autonomous weapons.â€ Late on Friday, rival OpenAI, which is backed by Microsoft, Amazon and others, announced its own deal to deploy technology in the Defence Departmentâ€™s classified network. CEO Sam Altman on X said the Pentagon shared its principles for human responsibility over weapon systems and for having no mass US surveillance. â€œWe put them into our agreement,â€ Altman said of the points. â€œWe also will build technical safeguards to ensure our models behave as they should, which the DoW also wanted.â€ It was not immediately clear whether these contractual details differed from the red lines proposed by Anthropic. The Pentagon and OpenAI did not immediately respond to a request for comment. â€˜Nuclear Warâ€™ Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth said Anthropic would be designated a supply-chain risk, following an impasse in months of talks on whether the companyâ€™s policies could constrain military action. Meeting with Hegseth this week, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei argued for weapons and surveillance limits and irked Pentagon officials. The Pentagon said US law, not a private company, would determine how to defend the country. The designation could bar tens of thousands of contractors from using Anthropicâ€™s AI when working for the Pentagon. That represents an existential threat to its business with the government and could harm its private-sector relationships, said Franklin Turner, an attorney who specialises in government contracts. â€œBlacklisting Anthropic is the contractual equivalent of nuclear war,â€ he said. Similar US action was taken to remove Chinese tech giant Huawei from the Pentagonâ€™s supply chains. Starting in 2017, the US restricted Defence Department use of Huawei equipment, prohibited federal agencies from purchasing its technology, and halted federal grant and loan funds for Huawei equipment. A rapprochement ensued with companies including Amazon and Microsoft jousting for defence business, while several big-tech CEOs pledged co-operation last year with the Trump administration. But theoretical â€œkiller robotsâ€ have worried human-rights and technology activists as wars in Ukraine and Gaza showcased increasingly automated systems. Bolder US military action in the past year has added to these concerns, said Jack Shanahan, who had directed the Pentagonâ€™s algorithmic warfare effort Project Maven. â€œPeople might be a little bit more nervous about no restrictions,â€ Shanahan said. The White Houseâ€™s legal sign-off could be â€œtop cover for anybody that does anything that would potentially result in lack of due process, civilian casualties, collateral damage.â€ The Pentagon signed agreements worth up to $200 million each with major AI labs in the past year, including Anthropic, OpenAI and Google. Anthropic, negotiating for awards under that ceiling, had flagged concerns about the legal systemâ€™s ability to keep up with AI progress. At present, for instance, US laws do not prevent the use of technology to compile seemingly innocuous data to reveal information about peopleâ€™s private lives, its CEO Amodei has said. Anthropicâ€™s AI has been in use across the intelligence community and armed services, and it was first among peer AI companies to work with classified information, through a supply deal via cloud provider Amazon.

items.title_orig: Russia may interfere in Danish election, exploiting chaos sown by US, spies warn
items.summary_orig: US threats to seize Greenland have created â€˜new international fault linesâ€™ that can be used to spread disinformation, Danish intelligence agencies say Denmarkâ€™s intelligence services have warned that a foreign power may try to sway the general election on 24 March, saying the main threat was from Russia over support for Ukraine but also citing the chaos caused by US efforts to seize Greenland. The PET police intelligence service and FE military intelligence said in a joint statement the election campaign could be marked by disinformation and cyberattacks â€œto sow division, influence the public debate or to target candidates, parties or specific political programmesâ€. Continue reading...

items.title_orig: UN terms violence against women â€˜a global emergencyâ€™
items.summary_orig: GENEVA: The UN rights chief has decried mounting threats to womenâ€™s rights worldwide, highlighting rampant femicide and horrific abuse exposed in cases like that of US sex offender Jefferey Epstein. Addressing the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva, Volker Turk slammed â€œsocial systems that silence women and girlsâ€ and allow powerful men to abuse them with impunity. â€œViolence against women, including femicide, is a global emergency,â€ the High Commissioner for Human Rights told the UNâ€™s top rights body. He highlighted the extreme situation in Afghanistan, warning that the â€œsystem of segregation imposed on women is reminiscent of apartheid, based on gender rather than raceâ€. He also pointed to two cases that have recently caused shock waves around the world: those of convicted Epstein and of French rape survivor Gisele Pelicot. Both cases â€œshow the extent of the exploitation and abuse of women and girlsâ€, Turk said, asking: â€œdoes anyone think there are not many more men like Dominique Pelicot or Jeffrey Epstein?â€ Epstein associated with the worldâ€™s rich, famous and powerful despite his conviction in 2008 to procuring a child for prostitution. He died in a New York jail cell in 2019 while facing trial on sex trafficking charges. His death was ruled a suicide. Gisele Pelicot gave the public insight into her shocking case when she waived her right to anonymity during the 2024 trial in France of her ex-husband Dominique and dozens of strangers who he brought in to rape her while she was unconscious. â€œSuch horrific abuse is enabled by social systems that silence women and girls, and insulate powerful men from accountability,â€ Turk charged. â€œStates must investigate all alleged crimes, protect survivors, and ensure justice without fear or favour,â€ he insisted.Â­ Published in Dawn, February 28th, 2026

items.title_orig: Imaan, Hadiâ€™s pleas against sentence adjourned
items.summary_orig: human rights lawyer Imaan Mazari (right) with her husband Hadi Ali Chattha during a court hearing.â€”AFP/file ISLAMABAD: The Islamabad High Court on Friday adjourned the hearing of applications seeking suspension of sentence filed by lawyer and rights activists Imaan Mazari and Hadi Ali ChatÂ­tha in the controversial tweets case, as the defence pressed for an early date before Eid. Justice Muhammad Asif took up the matter amid a request from the state to transfer the appeal to another bench. During the proceedings, the assistant attorney general submitted that a case of similar nature had earlier been heard by Justice Azam Khan and requesÂ­ted that the present appeal also be placed before his court. He argued that it would be appropriate for the same bench to hear related matters. Rights activists granted bail by anti-terrorism court in two other cases However, the counsel for the appellants, Advocate Riasat Ali Azad, opposed the request, maintaining that no such case was pending before any other court of the country. He pointed out that the present appeal had been heard by JusÂ­tice Muhammad Asif since its inception and questioned how the government could raise objections to the bench at this stage. Expressing full confidence in the court, Mr Azad urged the juÂ­Â­dge to fix the matter for hearing before Eid, saying an early date would bring relief to his clients. Justice Asif asked the state to clarify which case was pending before Justice Azam Khan. Observers present in the courtroom noted that while other cases involving the accused might be pending elsewhere, the instant appeal had consistently remained before the same bench. The judge later rose and proceeded to his chambers after reÂ­Â­marking, â€œLetâ€™s see,â€ in response to the request for an early date. The state counsel informed the court that it had no objection if a date was fixed. Subsequently, the hearing was adjourned without immediate scheduling of the suspension pleas. Bail granted In a separate development, Anti-Terrorism Court Judge Abul Hasanat Muhammad Zulqarnain granted bail to Ms Mazari and Mr Chattha in two other cases. The bail was allowed against surety bonds of Rs5,000 each in cases related to an alleged scuffle outside the Islamabad High Court and a protest outside the National Press Club. In the case concerning the alÂ­Â­leged altercation outside the high court, an affidavit submitted by the complainant and Islamabad High Court Bar Association president Syed Wajid Ali Gillani was made part of the record. However, in the controversial tweets case â€” in which both rights activists have been convicted â€” bail has yet to be granted. Owing to the absence of relief in that matter, their release remains subject to the outcome of the pending suspension of sentence applications before the high court. Published in Dawn, February 28th, 2026

He pointed out that the present appeal had been heard by JusÂ­tice Muhammad Asif since its inception and questioned how the government could raise objections to the bench at this stage. Expressing full confidence in the court, Mr Azad urged the juÂ­Â­dge to fix the matter for hearing before Eid, saying an early date would bring relief to his clients. Justice Asif asked the state to clarify which case was pending before Justice Azam Khan. Observers present in the courtroom noted that while other cases involving the accused might be pending elsewhere, the instant appeal had consistently remained before the same bench. The judge later rose and proceeded to his chambers after reÂ­Â­marking, â€œLetâ€™s see,â€ in response to the request for an early date. The state counsel informed the court that it had no objection if a date was fixed. Subsequently, the hearing was adjourned without immediate scheduling of the suspension pleas. Bail granted In a separate development, Anti-Terrorism Court Judge Abul Hasanat Muhammad Zulqarnain granted bail to Ms Mazari and Mr Chattha in two other cases. The bail was allowed against surety bonds of Rs5,000 each in cases related to an alleged scuffle outside the Islamabad High Court and a protest outside the National Press Club. In the case concerning the alÂ­Â­leged altercation outside the high court, an affidavit submitted by the complainant and Islamabad High Court Bar Association president Syed Wajid Ali Gillani was made part of the record. However, in the controversial tweets case â€” in which both rights activists have been convicted â€” bail has yet to be granted. Owing to the absence of relief in that matter, their release remains subject to the outcome of the pending suspension of sentence applications before the high court. Published in Dawn, February 28th, 2026

items.title_orig: Israeli strikes kill seven more Palestinians across Gaza
items.summary_orig: â€¢ Israelâ€™s Supreme Court freezes ban on foreign aid organisations in enclave â€¢ US public sympathy shifts to Palestinians over Israel, new Gallup poll reveals CAIRO: Relentless Israeli attacks killed at least seven Palestinians in Gaza on Friday, medics said, adding to a death toll of at least 600 people killed by Israeli fire since a US-brokered ceasefire agreement came into effect last October. Gazaâ€™s health officials reported that in southern Gaza, five people were killed and several others were injured, some critically, in Israeli drone strikes. The strikes targeted two police checkpoints in Khan Yunis and in the Abu Hujair area northwest of the Bureij refugee camp later in the day, medics said. Separately, an Israeli airstrike against a group of Palestinians in Gaza Cityâ€™s Tuffah neighbourhood in northern Gaza killed two people and wounded several others. Ban on NGOs frozen Meanwhile, Israelâ€™s Supreme Court decided in a ruling published on Friday to freeze a government ban on 37 foreign NGOs working in Gaza and the occupied West Bank pending a final decision. â€œWithout taking any position, a temporary interim order is hereby issued,â€ the court said in a ruling responding to a petition from more than a dozen NGOs, seeking to reverse the ban after Israelâ€™s government revoked their status in Israel. The decision theoretically allows the NGOs to work in Gaza and the West Bank until a final ruling, but aid groups are unsure about the freezeâ€™s implementation. Organisations like MSF, Oxfam, the Norwegian Refugee Council, and CARE were informed on Dec 30, 2025, that their Israeli registrations expired and they had 60 days to renew them by providing Palestinian staff lists. If they failed to do so, they would have to cease operations in Gaza and the West Bank, including east Jerusalem, from March 1. The NGOs, through AIDA, petitioned the Supreme Court after losing their charity registration in Israel, following a year-long refusal to disclose their Palestinian employees to Israeli authorities. The court said in its ruling that there existed a â€œgenuine legal disputeâ€ due to the foreign NGOsâ€™ responsibilities to their employeesâ€™ privacy under European law. â€œWe are still waiting to see how the injunction will be interpreted by the state and whether or not this will mean an increase in our ability to operateâ€, Athena Rayburn, AIDA director, told AFP, calling it â€œa step in the right directionâ€. Sympathy shifts to Palestinians Separately, a fresh Gallup poll shows that for the first time, Americans sympathise more with Palestinians than with Israelis in their decades-long conflict. The poll, released on Friday, found that 41 per cent of Americans sympathise more with the Palestinians and 36pc sided with Israel, a sharp reversal from just a year ago when Israel led in sympathies 46 to 33pc. For the first time in over two decades, Israel is not leading in Gallupâ€™s poll, though the gap is not significant. Partisan views on the Middle East show more independents shifting towards Palestinians, with an 11-point preference over Israel in the past year. Democrats overwhelmingly support Palestinians, with 65pc sympathising with them versus 17pc for Israel. Democrats blame ex-president Joe Biden for insufficient action to curb Israelâ€™s offensive in Gaza after October 7,2023, escalation. Gallup surveyed 1,001 US adults by telephone from February 2 to 16. Published in Dawn, February 28th, 2026

items.title_orig: Taliban now â€˜amenable to talksâ€™ as world urges de-escalation
items.summary_orig: â€¢ Qatar, Saudi Arabia lead diplomatic scramble; Iran offers to facilitate talks â€¢ Trump â€˜refusesâ€™ to intervene because of â€˜fondnessâ€™ for Pakistan â€¢ UN, China, Russia, UK call for immediate ceasefire ISLAMABAD: Afghanistanâ€™s Taliban rulers said on Friday they were willing to negotiate after Pakistan unleashed air strikes on major Afghan cities, killing dozens in the most serious clashes between the allies-turned-foes, which Defence Minister Khawaja Asif described as an â€œopen warâ€. The Afghan Taliban, who claimed to have launched â€œretaliatory attacksâ€ over strikes against terroristsâ€™ hideouts last weekend, said on Friday that they were â€œready for dialogueâ€. â€œAfghanistanâ€¦ has always preferred to resoÂ­lve issues based on mutual understanding and respect,â€ the Afghan foreign ministry quoted Foreign Minister Amir Khan Muttaqi as telling Qatarâ€™s junior Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulaziz Al-Khalifi by telephone. Taliban spokesperson Zabihullah Mujahid echoed that sentiment, saying â€œnow also we want to resolve this matter through dialogueâ€. Key regional powers are also quickly mobilising to prevent the conflict from spiralling. Iran, which borders both nations, offered to mediate. â€œThe Islamic Republic of Iran stands ready to provide any assistance necessary to facilitate dialogue and to enhance understanding and cooperation between the two countries,â€ Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said in a post on X. Saudi Arabia and Qatar were also engaged in a diplomatic drive to halt the hostilities, a source with knowledge of the talks told AFP. â€œSaudi Arabia, in coordination with Qatar, is making efforts to reduce tensions between Pakistan and Afghanistan,â€ the source said, adding the goal is to â€œde-escalate the situation and prevent it from spiralling out of controlâ€. Saudi Arabiaâ€™s Foreign Minister, Prince Faisal bin Farhan, in a phone call with his Afghan counterpart Muttaqi, expressed concern over the recent situation. Meanwhile, during a phone call with PakiÂ­stanâ€™s Ishaq Dar, the Saudi foreign minister agreed to stay closely engaged. Similarly, Turkish ForeÂ­ign Minister Hakan Fidan held separate calls with his counterparts from PakiÂ­stan, Afghanistan, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia to discuss the conflict, a Turkish diplomatic source said. From Moscow to Beijing, international powers also issued urgent calls for de-escalation. China, a neighbour and major investor in the region, expressed deep concern over the violence. â€œChina supports combating all forms of terrorism and calls on both parties to remain calm and exercise restraint, properly resolve differences through dialogue and negotiation, achieve a ceasefire as soon as possible, and avoid further loss of life,â€ Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said. She confirmed that China was mediating through its own channels and had requested both sides ensure the safety of Chinese personnel and projects. Moscow urged an immediate halt to the attacks and a return to diplomacy. Russia, which is the only country to officially recognise the Taliban government and also maintains good relations with Pakistan, said the clashes were a dangerous development. â€œWe call on our friends Afghanistan and Pakistan to abandon this dangerous confrontation and return to the negotiating table to resolve all differences through political and diplomatic means,â€ Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova wrote on Telegram. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov added that Moscow was â€œclosely monitoring this situation.â€ From Europe, Britain expressed grave concern. â€œWe are deeply concerned by the significant escalation in tensions between Afghanistan and Pakistan,â€ UK Foreign Minister Yvette Cooper said on X. â€œWe urge both sides to take immediate steps toward de-escalation, avoid further harm to civilians, and re-engage in mediated dialogue.â€ Meanwhile, US President Donald Trump, known for his enthusiasm in mediating conflicts and a strong desire for a Nobel Peace Prize, offered a stance that diverged from his usual eagerness to resolve disputes. In Washington, Trump suggested he would not be willing to step in, highlighting his strong ties with Pakistanâ€™s leadership. SpeÂ­aking to reporters before heading to Texas, Trump was asked about Pakistanâ€™s retaliation to unprovoked aggression by the Afghan Taliban. Asked whether someone had asked for him to intervene, Trump said, â€œWell, I would but I get along with Pakistan, as you know, very well. Very, very well. â€œ[They] have a great prime minister, a great general there â€¦ two of the people I really respect a lot,â€ he said. â€œAnd I think that Pakistan is doing terrifically well,â€ he said. The United Nations added its voice to the global chorus for peace. UN Secretary-General AntÂ­onio Guterres â€œis deeply concerned by the escalation of violence weâ€™re seeing,â€ his spokesman StepÂ­hane Dujarric said. â€œHe calls for an immediate cessation of hostilities, and he reiterates his call on the parties to resolve any differences through diplomacy.â€ The International CommÂ­Â­ittee of the Red Cross also echoed calls to protect civilians. The organisationâ€™s president has called for a de-escalation of hostilities between Afghanistan and Pakistan, AFP reports. ICRC President Mirjana Spoljaric said in a statement that her organisation was â€œpreparing an operational response to humanitarian needs on the groundâ€. Published in Dawn, February 28th, 2026

UN Secretary-General AntÂ­onio Guterres â€œis deeply concerned by the escalation of violence weâ€™re seeing,â€ his spokesman StepÂ­hane Dujarric said. â€œHe calls for an immediate cessation of hostilities, and he reiterates his call on the parties to resolve any differences through diplomacy.â€ The International CommÂ­Â­ittee of the Red Cross also echoed calls to protect civilians. The organisationâ€™s president has called for a de-escalation of hostilities between Afghanistan and Pakistan, AFP reports. ICRC President Mirjana Spoljaric said in a statement that her organisation was â€œpreparing an operational response to humanitarian needs on the groundâ€. Published in Dawn, February 28th, 2026

items.title_orig: With presidential ordinance set to lapse, Senate passes bill for regulating virtual assets
items.summary_orig: ISLAMABAD: The upper House of Parliament on Friday passed a bill for regulating virtual assets as well as the â€˜establishmentâ€™ of the Pakistan Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority (PVARA) â€” a body already set up under an ordinance approved by the president in July last year. The development comes as the ordinance was set to lapse in early March. The rules were suspended in the Senate to take up the bill, which was moved by Finance Minister Muhammad Aurangzeb, for immediate consideration. The preamble of the bill, a copy of which is available with Dawn , stated that it was expedient to establish a dedicated virtual assets regulatory authority to licence, regulate and supervise virtual assets and virtual asset service providers to â€œensure investor protection, transparency and market integrity in Pakistanâ€. It further stated that it was necessary to provide a comprehensive legal framework to empower the said authority to combat money laundering, terrorist financing, proliferation financing and other illicit activities involving virtual assets, in accordance with international standards. Regulatory authority The bill provides for the establishment of the Pakistan Virtual Asset Regulatory Authority, envisioning it as an autonomous corporate body empowered to licence, regulate and supervise virtual asset service providers and issuers in the country. Elaborating on the bodyâ€™s functions, the legislation says it will â€œprotect customers and investors and the integrity of Pakistanâ€™s virtual asset markets by establishing and enforcing appropriate safeguards and conduct of business requirements, prudential and operational-resilience, risk-management standards, and measures to prevent money laundering, terrorist financing and other illicit use of virtual assetsâ€. It shall also attract investment and encourage companies operating in the field of virtual assets to base their businesses in Pakistan. Moreover, PVARA shall â€œpromote responsible innovation, digital financial inclusion and the development of compliant virtual asset markets within a framework that manages risks and supports financial stability and market integrityâ€. The body shall promote, develop, govern, and regulate the adoption, deployment, and scalable use of blockchain technology and distributed ledger technology across Pakistan, the bill further states. The legislation also states that PVARA will coordinate with the Financial Monitoring Unit, National Anti-Money Laundering and Counter Financing of Terrorism Authority and other relevant authorities, as well as law enforcement agencies, to combat money laundering, terrorist financing and other illicit activities associated with virtual assets, in accordance with the Anti-Money Laundering Act, 2010, other applicable laws and international standards. The regulatory body will also advise the government on â€œregulatory, supervisory, technical or emerging-risk matters relating to virtual assets, digital asset markets, tokenisation, stablecoin structures, blockchain, distributed ledger technology, cyber-risks or any matter connected with its mandateâ€. The bill also authorises PVARA to devise â€œregulations, standards, directives, guidelines, handbooks and circulars, or any other instrumentâ€, consistent with the objectives of the legislation and other applicable laws. It will also be authorised to set risk-management, cybersecurity, data protection and technical standards and â€œissue, vary, suspend or revoke licences, approvals or directives under this Act and prescribe conditions for such actionsâ€. The bill further states that it may prescribe licencing conditions, eligibility criteria, renewal requirements and any additional obligations for those issued licences under the yet to be formalised PVARA law. It will also be authorised to conduct on-site inspections and off-site monitoring of licencees and other entities to ensure compliance with this PVARA law and other relevant rules and regulations. Moreover, the bill states, the body may also ensure compliance with â€œdata protection, data governance and cyber security obligations by virtual asset service providers subject to supervisory follow-upâ€. It will also be empowered to impose administrative sanctions in accordance with the provisions of the PVARA law and â€œlevy such fees, charges and penalties as may be prescribed by rulesâ€ devised under this law. PVARA will also operate regulatory sandboxes in a â€œtransparent and accountable mannerâ€ and â€œenter into cooperation or mutual assistance arrangements with domestic and foreign regulators and law enforcement agencies to facilitate information sharing and coordinated action, including mutual recognition of regulations and licencesâ€, the bill states. It further details that the body will comprise a chairperson â€” who will be appointed by the federal government â€” two secretaries, from the law and finance ministries each, State Bank of Pakistanâ€™s governor, Securities and Exchange Commission of Pakistan chairperson, National Anti-Money Laundering and Counter Financing of Terrorism Authority chairman, Pakistan Digital Authority chairperson and two independent directors â€œwith proven expertise and a strong track record possessing expertise relevant to virtual asset markets, digital technology and digital financeâ€. The directors will also be appointed by the federal government. â€œThe members of the authority, other than ex-officio members, shall hold office for a term of three years and shall be eligible for one further term of three years,â€ the bill states. Penalties The bill states that â€œwhoever, willfully, provides an unlicenced virtual asset service shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term up to five years, or with fine up to Rs50 million, or bothâ€. It adds that whoever conducts an initial virtual asset offering in contraventionâ€ of the rules and regulations established under the PVARA law shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term up to three years or with fine up to Rs25m or with both. The bill also penalises market manipulation and insider trading. It further states that â€œa virtual assets appellate tribunal shall be established and no court shall take cognisance of a legal dispute under this Act or the rules or regulations made thereunder to which the jurisdiction of the Virtual Assets Appellate Tribunal extendsâ€. The tribunalâ€™s jurisdiction has been described as: â€œAny virtual asset service provider, licencee, or any other person aggrieved by an order of the PVARA may prefer an appeal before the Virtual Assets Appellate Tribunal within 30 days of the date on which the order was communicated.â€ In July last year, the government had announced that President Asif Ali Zardari had approved the â€˜Virtual Assets Ordinance, 2025â€™ to establish an independent regulator for virtual assets and cryptocurrencies. However, an official statement from the office of the state minister referred to it as the â€˜Virtual Assets Act, 2025â€™, leading to confusion and concerns about why the draft law had not been moved to the National Assembly or Senate, as required for a bill to become an act of parliament. The confusion was clarified later when the authorities confirmed to Dawn that the regulation was not an act of parliament but rather an ordinance, issued under Article 89 of the Constitution. The provision allows the president to issue an ordinance in urgent matters when both houses are not in session; such ordinances remain in effect for 120 days and do not require passage through the National Assembly and Senate. In November last year, the Senate extended the Virtual Assets Ordinance, 2025 , for another 120 days.
items.title_en: With presidential ordinance set to lapse, Senate passes bill for regulating virtual assets
items.summary_en: ISLAMABAD: The upper House of Parliament on Friday passed a bill for regulating virtual assets as well as the â€˜establishmentâ€™ of the Pakistan Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority (PVARA) â€” a body already set up under an ordinance approved by the president in July last year. The development comes as the ordinance was set to lapse in early March. The rules were suspended in the Senate to take up the bill, which was moved by Finance Minister Muhammad Aurangzeb, for immediate consideration. The preamble of the bill, a copy of which is available with Dawn , stated that it was expedient to establish a dedicated virtual assets regulatory authority to licence, regulate and supervise virtual assets and virtual asset service providers to â€œensure investor protection, transparency and market integrity in Pakistanâ€. It further stated that it was necessary to provide a comprehensive legal framework to empower the said authority to combat money laundering, terrorist financing, proliferation financing and other illicit activities involving virtual assets, in accordance with international standards. Regulatory authority The bill provides for the establishment of the Pakistan Virtual Asset Regulatory Authority, envisioning it as an autonomous corporate body empowered to licence, regulate and supervise virtual asset service providers and issuers in the country. Elaborating on the bodyâ€™s functions, the legislation says it will â€œprotect customers and investors and the integrity of Pakistanâ€™s virtual asset markets by establishing and enforcing appropriate safeguards and conduct of business requirements, prudential and operational-resilience, risk-management standards, and measures to prevent money laundering, terrorist financing and other illicit use of virtual assetsâ€. It shall also attract investment and encourage companies operating in the field of virtual assets to base their businesses in Pakistan. Moreover, PVARA shall â€œpromote responsible innovation, digital financial inclusion and the development of compliant virtual asset markets within a framework that manages risks and supports financial stability and market integrityâ€. The body shall promote, develop, govern, and regulate the adoption, deployment, and scalable use of blockchain technology and distributed ledger technology across Pakistan, the bill further states. The legislation also states that PVARA will coordinate with the Financial Monitoring Unit, National Anti-Money Laundering and Counter Financing of Terrorism Authority and other relevant authorities, as well as law enforcement agencies, to combat money laundering, terrorist financing and other illicit activities associated with virtual assets, in accordance with the Anti-Money Laundering Act, 2010, other applicable laws and international standards. The regulatory body will also advise the government on â€œregulatory, supervisory, technical or emerging-risk matters relating to virtual assets, digital asset markets, tokenisation, stablecoin structures, blockchain, distributed ledger technology, cyber-risks or any matter connected with its mandateâ€. The bill also authorises PVARA to devise â€œregulations, standards, directives, guidelines, handbooks and circulars, or any other instrumentâ€, consistent with the objectives of the legislation and other applicable laws. It will also be authorised to set risk-management, cybersecurity, data protection and technical standards and â€œissue, vary, suspend or revoke licences, approvals or directives under this Act and prescribe conditions for such actionsâ€. The bill further states that it may prescribe licencing conditions, eligibility criteria, renewal requirements and any additional obligations for those issued licences under the yet to be formalised PVARA law. It will also be authorised to conduct on-site inspections and off-site monitoring of licencees and other entities to ensure compliance with this PVARA law and other relevant rules and regulations. Moreover, the bill states, the body may also ensure compliance with â€œdata protection, data governance and cyber security obligations by virtual asset service providers subject to supervisory follow-upâ€. It will also be empowered to impose administrative sanctions in accordance with the provisions of the PVARA law and â€œlevy such fees, charges and penalties as may be prescribed by rulesâ€ devised under this law. PVARA will also operate regulatory sandboxes in a â€œtransparent and accountable mannerâ€ and â€œenter into cooperation or mutual assistance arrangements with domestic and foreign regulators and law enforcement agencies to facilitate information sharing and coordinated action, including mutual recognition of regulations and licencesâ€, the bill states. It further details that the body will comprise a chairperson â€” who will be appointed by the federal government â€” two secretaries, from the law and finance ministries each, State Bank of Pakistanâ€™s governor, Securities and Exchange Commission of Pakistan chairperson, National Anti-Money Laundering and Counter Financing of Terrorism Authority chairman, Pakistan Digital Authority chairperson and two independent directors â€œwith proven expertise and a strong track record possessing expertise relevant to virtual asset markets, digital technology and digital financeâ€. The directors will also be appointed by the federal government. â€œThe members of the authority, other than ex-officio members, shall hold office for a term of three years and shall be eligible for one further term of three years,â€ the bill states. Penalties The bill states that â€œwhoever, willfully, provides an unlicenced virtual asset service shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term up to five years, or with fine up to Rs50 million, or bothâ€. It adds that whoever conducts an initial virtual asset offering in contraventionâ€ of the rules and regulations established under the PVARA law shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term up to three years or with fine up to Rs25m or with both. The bill also penalises market manipulation and insider trading. It further states that â€œa virtual assets appellate tribunal shall be established and no court shall take cognisance of a legal dispute under this Act or the rules or regulations made thereunder to which the jurisdiction of the Virtual Assets Appellate Tribunal extendsâ€. The tribunalâ€™s jurisdiction has been described as: â€œAny virtual asset service provider, licencee, or any other person aggrieved by an order of the PVARA may prefer an appeal before the Virtual Assets Appellate Tribunal within 30 days of the date on which the order was communicated.â€ In July last year, the government had announced that President Asif Ali Zardari had approved the â€˜Virtual Assets Ordinance, 2025â€™ to establish an independent regulator for virtual assets and cryptocurrencies. However, an official statement from the office of the state minister referred to it as the â€˜Virtual Assets Act, 2025â€™, leading to confusion and concerns about why the draft law had not been moved to the National Assembly or Senate, as required for a bill to become an act of parliament. The confusion was clarified later when the authorities confirmed to Dawn that the regulation was not an act of parliament but rather an ordinance, issued under Article 89 of the Constitution. The provision allows the president to issue an ordinance in urgent matters when both houses are not in session; such ordinances remain in effect for 120 days and do not require passage through the National Assembly and Senate. In November last year, the Senate extended the Virtual Assets Ordinance, 2025 , for another 120 days.

items.title_orig: Trump 'not thrilled' with Iran talks progress, contemplates military action
items.summary_orig: Top US diplomat Marco Rubio is set to embark on a two-day visit to Israel early next week as tensions remain high following the latest nuclear talks between Washington and Tehran. Travel advisories to Israel have been issued by many countries, prompting many to believe a US attack may be imminent.

items.title_orig: Pakistanâ€™s patience runs out after badly miscalculating over Taliban
items.summary_orig: Military reckoned â€˜goodâ€™ Afghan insurgents were separate from â€˜badâ€™ Pakistani insurgents but distinction has blurred Days after the Taliban swept to power in 2021, Pakistanâ€™s then spymaster appeared in Kabul on what looked to many like a victory lap. Sipping tea in the lobby of the Afghan capitalâ€™s fanciest hotel, Lt Gen Faiz Hameed told reporters: â€œDonâ€™t worry, everything will be OK.â€ This week it became clear just how badly Pakistan had miscalculated how it could rely on the Taliban, as Islamabad unleashed airstrikes in Afghanistan and troops from both countries fought each other on the border. Continue reading...
